channel.title: mjec's electric blogaloo
channel.description: Recent content on mjec's electric blogaloo

item.title: How many atoms are there in an amoeba?
item.description: I asked this question of my father when I was 4 years old. This is his answer.
2016 was a terrible year for the world, but a great year for me.

item.title: Australia should not adopt electronic voting
item.description: There's been some talk recently about electronic voting in Australia. Here are my thoughts on why we shouldn't move away from the paper voting system.

item.title: RC return statement
item.description: A few reflections on my time at the Recurse Center.

item.title: Reflections on New York City
item.description: I've been here three months now, and I love this city.

item.title: Django's QuerySet union isn't quite what it seems
item.description: Django claims that QuerySets support a union operator. It turns out that doesn't actually give you a union of two query sets, and it can silently munge your query.

item.title: Your RDBMS has cool features
item.description: There are plenty of cool features in relational database management systems (e.g. PostgreSQL, MariaDB). It turns out it actually makes sense to use them when building applications.

item.title: Liking problematic media
item.description: Sometimes it's nice to enjoy things that aren't so nice. And that might be okay, as long as you are willing to acknowledge its problems. (Note that this post uses and discusses strong profanity, gendered and racist slurs.)

item.title: Non-proofs
item.description: I've enjoyed reading a few spurious proofs today

item.title: An idea for trusted brute-force-resistant two-factor-authenticated full disk encryption
item.description: Combining a trusted platform module with a smart card (e.g. YubiKey) enables trusted booting with full disk encryption and without the ability to brute force passwords.

item.title: My Haskell was slow
item.description: This is how I fixed it, blogged live.

item.title: Finding subsets with particular sums
item.description: Given a list L and a sum S, what's the best way to find x, y in L such that x + y = S? What about a set of n integers with that sum, instead of a pair? I don't have a good answer for the second question; suggestions welcome!

item.title: Fibonacci numbers and the golden ratio
item.description: In which I solve exercise 1.13 of Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs

item.title: Some weeks are better than others
item.description: Last week was amazing. The weekend sucked. And now I'm struggling.

item.title: Learning Haskell
item.description: I have started to learn Haskell. It's amazing.

item.title: RC Day One
item.description: I think I'm going to fit in here

item.title: Day one
item.description: In which I explore the city a bit.

item.title: I have arrived
item.description: New York City, I am in you.

item.title: Travelling is hard
item.description: Flying sucks. Packing is much worse.

item.title: Yet another new beginning
item.description: I've decided to start a blog. Again.
